content.raw: I'd remove this block because it won't work when you prevent to create a `SubscriptionMsg` with a large topic in a future pull request.
content.html: I'd remove this block because it won't work when you prevent to create a SubscriptionMsg with a large topic in a future pull request.

I'd use a valid AdvertiseMsg in this block and manually modify its topicLength field:

// Set the topic length to an illegal value.
uint64_t topicLength = maxTopicLength + 1;
memcpy(pBody, &topicLength, sizeof(topicLength));

content.raw:
Your pull request made me think another alternative:

Right now, the topic length field is a `uint64_t`, allowing a really huge string with its potential security risks. Our initial though was to keep the same field but check that the value is not bigger than `255` octets for example. Another idea is to change `uint64_t` to a `uint8_t` or a `uint16_t` and not check its value in `Unpack()`, just allow the entire range of potential values. This will reduce the footprint of the message, processing time and code complexity as we don't have to check anything.

`uint8_t` would be ideal for ASCII but if someone uses Unicode, 256 octets looks small to me. For example UTF-8 can use up to 4 bytes per character, allowing only the transfer of 64 characters. I propose to use a `uint16_t` field that should be more than enough to transfer any topic and won't cause a security thread because the maximum size would be a few KB.

@nampi , what do you think?
content.html:
Your pull request made me think another alternative:

Right now, the topic length field is a uint64_t, allowing a really huge string with its potential security risks. Our initial though was to keep the same field but check that the value is not bigger than 255 octets for example. Another idea is to change uint64_t to a uint8_t or a uint16_t and not check its value in Unpack(), just allow the entire range of potential values. This will reduce the footprint of the message, processing time and code complexity as we don't have to check anything.

uint8_t would be ideal for ASCII but if someone uses Unicode, 256 octets looks small to me. For example UTF-8 can use up to 4 bytes per character, allowing only the transfer of 64 characters. I propose to use a uint16_t field that should be more than enough to transfer any topic and won't cause a security thread because the maximum size would be a few KB.

@nampi , what do you think?

content.raw: @caguero I agree with you. I have created a new pull request with this approach. Should I close this pr?
content.html: @caguero I agree with you. I have created a new pull request with this approach. Should I close this pr?

content.raw: If this PR is not complementary or it is implementing an old approach, please do it. Only pull-requests ready to discuss for merging should remain open. We can re-open it at any moment in the future if needed.
content.html: If this PR is not complementary or it is implementing an old approach, please do it. Only pull-requests ready to discuss for merging should remain open. We can re-open it at any moment in the future if needed.
